item.title: By: Aaron Koller
item.dc:creator: Aaron Koller
item.description: Nothing to add about the Bible issues. But on the social front, it may sounds brutal, but it's likely true that the Jewish future will come from those who don't intermarry. Pew found that 17% of people who said they were partly Jewish were raising their children as Jewish. So while it might not be kind, what grounds are there for disagreeing with Bayme's assessment that the community should pour all its resources into those not (and not yet) intermarried?

item.title: By: Steve Brizel
item.dc:creator: Steve Brizel
item.description: Dr. Bayme taught a superb course on the Holocaust which I took at YU. The readings, lectures and discussions were outstanding and gave me a great insight into the various factors that led to the rise of Nazism and the Holocaust. I also audited Dr. Bayme's course on Jewish history, and found many of the sources incompatible and well beyond the pale of standard Orthodox hashkafa. The facts remain that R Lichtenstein, both in the 1960s and in the YU Judaica book , set forth where he disagreed with R Greenberg.

item.title: By: Yonatan
item.dc:creator: Yonatan
item.description:
If one accepts genuine denominational pluralism within Judaism and the validity of Conservative and/or Reform approaches to Halakhah, why bother with "Partnership Minyanim" or other recently liberal Modern Orthodox innovations? Why not just have complete egalitarian minyanim?
Either Conservative Judaism's approach to Halakhah is wrong (and therefore pluralism is rejected) and that is why one is limited to creative innovations like "Women's Tefillah Groups" or "Partnership Minyanim" or it is correct and their is no need for liberal Modern Orthodox inventions as any such needs could be fulfilled within Conservative Synagogues.
As Yitz Greenberg’s theology includes the non-binding nature of Halakha and the acceptance of Jesus as a failed Messiah how is his theology Orthodox (even Modern Orthodox)?

item.title: By: ben dov
item.dc:creator: ben dov
item.description:
"Portions of it [Torah]may be rooted in different historical records, but that does not make the text less authoritative as a work of theology. What does make it authoritative is that it is the inheritance of the Jewish people-morasha beit yaacov."
No, what makes it authoritative is that G-d is the sole author. Mr. Bayme's view is classic non-Orthodox theology.
